In principle this makes sense. Some of the doc still needs to be updated, and we should probably update swiftclient to use sha256 before deprecating sha1.

Those DSVM failures are weird... not sure what's up with them. I was thinking it was just eventual consistency issues at first, but that seems less likely given how frequently they're failing.

We should probably update the algorithm used by the func tests so we don't skip *quite* so many tempurl tests.

> Those DSVM failures are weird... not sure what's up with them. I was thinking it was just eventual consistency issues at first, but that seems less likely given how frequently they're failing.

Amazingly enough Zuul kept the failed console log long enough for me to examine today. The log seems to indicate to me that the difference grows for each failed test. All tests fail where the assert expects 10 elements, but gets more and more and more. So, I suspect, something is not being reset properly between tests and the new ones run over dirty containers.

Remember that functests do not start and stop services - I used to run functests over a production cluster. They literally go and delete all containers and objects.

It's possible that eventual consistency of container listings is what we're seeing. Maybe someone forgot to start an updater.

I agree with all of Alistair's comments.

swiftclient does not support this new signature format

https://bugs.launchpad.net/python-swiftclient/+bug/1977867

When you upgrade to a version of swift that includes this change you break your clients (unless you change your config according to UpgradeImpact)

I don't think this is how we should be rolling out deprecations in general - IMHO it's going to cause a fire drill for a bunch of ops people (who we claim we like!) for no good reason.  So why'd we do it like this?

Indeed the experience is not smooth.

Suppose a cluster existed that had all the middlewares, but with null configuration (all defaults). If nobody even used tempurl, then this warning is pointless: the cluster is automatically sound after upgrade. But if someone did use tempurl, then the new cluster disallows it, and they'll know once their client scripts fail.

In fact I think this deprecation warning may actually be pointless. Operator will know what happens from reading the code anyway. User has no access to logs and cannot see the warning.

Are we sure we want to back out the getattr stuff? Passing a str seems to put us down a code path like https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/v3.9.10/Lib/hmac.py#L60-L61, which feels suspiciously like what we were doing before https://github.com/openstack/swift/commit/471a559a

swift/common/utils.py.message: Should we default this parameter to a deprecated digest? Is it due to swift tools?

My guess would be backwards compatibility. Both for legecy 3rd party and upstream,. It's hard to support legacy tools out there that we don't even know exist. But also for upgrades, when you're upgrading a legecy cluster that has many nodes you will tend at somepoint to have a mix of nodes. Older ones are probably not sending the digest at all and assuming sha1.

I hope we start to explictly start using a better digest with all new swift nodes (and defaults). Then maybe in a release or 2 we can deprecate it completely and change this to something more reasonable.

Hmm, The get hmac method is also used in the proxy in particular admin requests. I don't see it providing the digest to use, so looks like that can be another patch to make that start using something better too!
OIC, we moved the getattr() here. But what's this about py2? Why's py3 exempted?
I stumbled upon this as well - hmac.new() in py2 requires a constructor or module as digest arg, in py3 it can be just the algo name (but it could still be the module as well).

Tested on centos8s in FIPS mode, with both Python 2.7.18 and 3.6.8 -- this seems to work fine.

(Curiously, I wasn't able to reproduce the trouble with functools that spurred me to write https://github.com/openstack/swift/commit/471a559a, but that's neither here nor there.)

test/unit/common/middleware/test_tempurl.message: we should retain some test that verifies sha1 works while it is still supported

I'm not sure if this suggestion is better to go on another patch, so you may ignore it.
We are changing the 'hashlib.sha1' in a lot of places, shouldn't we save it in a variable and just call that variable? In that case, if we need to change this again, we only need to change in one place.

Great suggestion! Adding the variable to the base tempurl unittest class as an instance variable would be a great improvement!
If it was in the main code I'd totally block (-1) on that, in the test code it's not so bad. We want to test a known expected thing so being specific in alot of these cases help prove that it works.

Another thing to note, is here we are mostly using the hashlib.<digest> methods because thats what python2 needs, this allows us to backport.
Going forward we'll be py3 only which means we can use the digest name as a string directly to hmac, so I wonder if we'd end up changing all this again soon anyway. That'll be a string so definitely should be a varaible.

cinder/db/sqlalchemy/api.py.message:
Note to reviewers: the only docs I could find for this (which is basically like the sqlalchemy begin_nested()) are the oslo.db unit tests:

https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.db/src/commit/95e1dd6e82e88b123a6118bf421464495d16f290/oslo_db/tests/sqlalchemy/test_enginefacade.py#L1892

If we did 'context.session.add(data)' then the actual session commit will happen when you exit the function. That means the try-except here is useless - the 'data.save()' call won't raise 'DBDuplicateEntry', only 'context.session.commit()' will. By using the context manager, the commit happens when we leave the "with" block so any exceptions will be raised immediately.

With that said, we don't need the decorator. I should drop that. Will post a follow-up shortly.
Can we have some more info regarding the usage of this and why context.session.add(data) is not correct here?

> > With that said, we don't need the decorator. I should drop that. Will post a follow-up shortly.
> 
> This is still true.

That's at [1]. I also posted a follow-up to the follow-up [2] that will remove the need for this entirely.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/844961
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/844962

> If we did 'context.session.add(data)' then the actual session commit will happen when you exit the function. That means the try-except here is useless - the 'data.save()' call won't raise 'DBDuplicateEntry', only 'context.session.commit()' will. By using the context manager, the commit happens when we leave the "with" block so any exceptions will be raised immediately.

Nope, I got this wrong. It's not because of when the commit happens. Rather, it's because we're not handling the exception (we return 'True' rather than raising a different exception). That means we try to commit the change [1] instead of rolling back the transaction [2]. You can prove this by removing this line. I'll add a note here.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.db/blob/3f889d5b6e/oslo_db/sqlalchemy/enginefacade.py#L659
[2] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.db/blob/3f889d5b6e/oslo_db/sqlalchemy/enginefacade.py#L660-L662

> With that said, we don't need the decorator. I should drop that. Will post a follow-up shortly.

This is still true.

Ack, thanks for the info.
If you plan to do a followup, please add a comment explaining this before the 'with' block so people are aware why we are doing it like this instead of the standard way of decorating the method.

manifests/profile/base/cinder/volume.pp.message:
I tend to skip this change because

 - to make this logic compatible with the other backends (except for ceph)

 - tripleo::profile:: ... hiera key has never worked properly and we can assume
   users would be using cinder::backend::nfs::volume_backend_name in existing
   deployments

The problem we're faced with is a historical inconsistency in whether THT and puppet-tripleo use hiera data in puppet-tripleo's or puppet-cinder's namespace. Many of the original cinder backends seem to have chose to use puppet-cinder hiera variables, but IMHO that was misguided because the puppet-cinder backends are all defined resources, where hiera bindings don't work. The whole design relies on puppet-tripleo to create the resources, so there should have been an incentive to use puppet-tripleo variables. I cringe each time I see a puppet-tripleo cinder backend (which is a puppet class) having to do a lookup() of another puppet-cinder variable.

In this situation, the THT patch [1] wants to emit puppet-tripleo hiera data, which works perfectly fine by overriding parameters in the tripleo::profile::base::cinder::volume::nfs puppet class.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/842370/3/deployment/cinder/cinder-volume-container-puppet.yaml#271

But that means *this* file needs to look up the puppet-tripleo variable. The double lookup, which falls back on looking up the legacy puppet-cinder variable, is added in order to avoid any possibility of a regression (something that's highly unlikely due to the tight coupling of THT and puppet-tripleo, but better safe than sorry).

Alan,

Thank you for your clarification and now I understand your point. I initially thought we'd use cinder::backend:: ... hieradata mainly but if we'd use tripleo::profile:: consistently in nfs backend then this makes sense.

manifests/profile/base/cinder/volume/nfs.message:
Several points regarding $cinder_nfs_shares_config:
- It should have a default value
- The previous code had it hard-coded to '/etc/cinder/shares-nfs.conf'
- But that's also cinder's own default value, so a better puppet default is $::os_service_default

So, I suggest changing this to "$cinder_nfs_shares_config = $::os_service_default" and moving it down between L74 and L75.
Please insert this to the consistent position (after cinder_nfs_mount_options). Also description of default value is missing.

In puppet-cinder, we intentionally hard-code this because this path is used to define the file resource.

https://github.com/openstack/puppet-cinder/blob/master/manifests/backend/nfs.pp#L127

So we should define the same default value, or alternatively use "undef" as default which eventually results in using the default defined in the underlying defined type.

I was the one who urged the use of $::os_service_default, but I agree with your comment. While it's fine to use $::os_service_default to let cinder choose a default value, I neglected the fact that puppet-cinder needs an actual value in order to create the File resource. Let's go back to using the original default value. I think it's better for puppet-tripleo to be explicit.

Thanks Takashi and Alan for the details.
I have used the same default value as in puppet-cinder.
this needs one more indent, to be placed in the consistent indent with L96
We can keep this now but we might just want to remove this because this has no effect in containerized deployment.

I discussed this with Manoj locally but this might need a few more consideration.

So if we have multiple nfs backend enabled, each backend tries to use this same file unless user gives CinderNfsSharesConfig. Also, the current file name is conflicting with what is used by netapp backend so users would face the same situation if they have both NetApp backend and Nfs backend enabled.

Ideally we should not use the common file name by default but the one unique per driver and backend, like /etc/cinder/shares-nfs-${backend}.conf . See what I proposed in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/puppet-tripleo/+/843579

My suggestion for your patch is

1. Use "undef" as the default value
2. If the value is not undef then use the given value (which is likely cause the problem when multiple backends are enabled)
3. If the value is undef then use '/etc/cinder/shares-nfs-${backend}.conf' (and let it overridden by CinderNfsSharesConfig.)

See my comment in the other patch https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/puppet-tripleo/+/843579

I would avoid worrying whether the user is deploying both NFS and NetApp backends. As I mentioned in that patch, this is simply not done in real world usage.

I also mentioned I OK with the code providing a fallback (default value) for the shares config file. But, the default file name doesn't need to include 'nfs', because the backend names for all cinder backends are already unique, and 'nfs' probably already appears in the backend name.

I dug back over the history of the NFS and Netapp backends. I think the problem here is the default value needs to match the old hard-coded value '/etc/cinder/shares-nfs.conf' (see L81 of the base file).

I learned the difference between "goto" and "jump" the hard way with iptables.
basically, "goto" is a dead-end, if nothing match, it just stops there. "jump" would drop the packet back to the upper chain.

For instance, INPUT goto(foo), and nothing match the packet in foo, it won't go forward; INPUT jump(foo), if nothing match in foo, packet will go back to INPUT and continue traversing the other existing rules, until it matches something (or fall in the INPUT policy).

tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_firewall/d.message:
before this change, I think the log all used to match only the packets being dropped?

Any changes introduced with that? We don't think any packets logged, until those to be dropped. That is performance related.

TL;DR: it's logging the packets that are about to be dropped by the INPUT policy

Longer explanation:
So basically, at this step, in a normal, NON-CI env, we're hitting the end of everything anyway. At this point, the next step is "jump back to INPUT chain"; in a standard, NON-CI env, there is no other chain than the TRIPLEO_INPUT, no other rules, meaning the packet will hit the INPUT chain policy, which is basically: "drop".

So that's what we had until now - just maybe a little bit less clearer. Also, there's the logging limit that will prevent issues, in case an operator wants to add some more custom things in their INPUT.

Does it answer your concern?

I don't understand why we would need the call to "multipathd reconfigure" at all. 

I'm inclined to think that either the os-brick code was using the reconfigure command as some kind of a wait/lock to prevent/reduce the error this patch is fixing, or it was done for some corner race condition cases were paths just went down and doing the resize would fail if multipathd hasn't updated the device mapper yet.

In my opinion we should remove the call, and that should reduce the number of cases where we see the timeout errors.

- With exception: The case I was seeing

"test_extend_volume_with_mpath_pending" covers the scenario in which the first resize map attempt receives a timeout error while the second call completes successfully, for which we're using the following side effect:

The one scenario that we haven't covered is the one in which the resize map call returns "timeout" indefinitely. I've just submitted another patch set that includes this as well.

I was looking at the code to verify this, and I'm not clear about why it works.

The affected drivers will be reporting something like this:

    { ... ,  "storage_protocol": ('nfs', 'NFS'), ... }

In the capabilities filter,
https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/src/commit/85387cae8b3641d6d193c6550edbfb0de1d8384e/cinder/scheduler/filters/capabilities_filter.py#L78
we have:
            # Make all capability values a list so we can handle lists
            cap_list = [cap] if not isinstance(cap, list) else cap

Since we're explicitly checking for a list and not an iterable, I believe what
will happen here is that cap_list will become:
  [('nfs', 'NFS')]

and then when we iterate through the values looking for a match, it will be
evaluated here:
https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/src/commit/85387cae8b3641d6d193c6550edbfb0de1d8384e/cinder/scheduler/filters/extra_specs_ops.py#L54
and we'll return

  return ('nfs', 'NFS') == 'nfs'

which won't match.  

I couldn't find anything explicitly testing tuples in the unit tests, but I may be looking in the wrong place, or maybe conversion to a list is happening somewhere else?

Thank you for the comment. The code was relying on how data is being serialized for RPC calls, where tuples are changed into lists.

The approach has been changed in the second patch, as agreed in the PTG, and drivers will not be sending multiple values.  Instead it's the schedulers that will adapt received values to map them.

It's not obvious to me that servers_per_port makes sense in a containerized world. (Why run one container that fans out to listen on a range of ports when you could run a container-per-port, each wanting to bind to 127.0.0.1:6200 or something, and have the container-runner map each to the appropriate port in the ring?)

If it *is* something we want, this seems like a reasonable way to approach it, though.

Should we update the replicator and reconciler, too? They both also want to know what IP to use when finding disks to process. Is the assumption that you'll want them running in separate container with separate configs? I feel like that's going to make it harder to make sure that things like reclaim_age are consistent across all the daemons.

-1: This doesn't need to be run as root, any user can read it, so we should read it from Python.

-1: It's not enough that 1 controller is connected, because there may be others connections that need to be done.

Example:

- There are 4 portals and there are issues in the paths to 3 of them.
- So the first attach only connects to 1 location out of 4.
- All paths recover now.
- Any following connections will NOT try the other 3 portals.
Agree, we should call connect_to_portal anyway and inside we should check if the controller exist before trying to connect
-1: If I'm not mistaken native multipath support cannot be enabled without a reboot, so we can just load this once and keep it a class attribute so we don't need to load it in all the executions.
get_nvme_controllers should return all live controllers, and fail only if no live controller is found
?: We should already have this information from earlier, right?
-1: We should get the controllers once, and then use it everywhere, right?
?: Have you tested this with a controller that is reconnecting due to network issues?  I believe this would fail either on the first request or the second one, I don't remember.
It's not related to the multipath change but I understood right this all rescan function should raise any exception?

What I mean is that blindly doing a rescan below will fail if the particular path is reconnecting due to network issues, and we'll end up with a long exception trace instead of a message saying that the particular path is down.

it's a nit, not a big deal.

-1: It would be ok if it were to add ANA support for the agent, but it looks like in this case it has nothing to do with ANA, which is the objective of the patch.
-1: Since we don't check the current value we are checking it on every single connection (because a new connector is created).  We should only check the system if the class attribute value is None.
nit: Maybe a warning here for the case where we were asked to do multipathing (it's not enforced) but we cannot do multipathing because native multipathing is not enabled.

-1: In theory we should fail if we receive the enforce_multipath parameter se to True but the system doesn't support ANA.

Unfortunately we cannot do that, because then we could break existing systems that are just using iSCSI/FC multipathing and don't care about this one.

On this same topic, it doesn't make sense that if we only use NVMe-oF connections and we want multipathing we need to install and run multipathd or Nova will fail to do the connection.

I think for now we should raise a warning here if we were requested to enforce multipathing but native multipathing is not supported, to at least make it clear WHY it's not doing multipathing.  That way at least the blame won't be on the os-brick code and will help operators.

I'll see if I can propose a patch to change our approach to the whole enforce multipathing feature to make it more reasonable.

In my opinion we should remove L121-123 for now, so method get_connector_properties doesn't log the warning.

That way deployments that only use iSCSI or FC with multipathing won't be seeing this warning on every single attach.
So, should we revert the whole enforce_multipath usage here and not log any warrning regards in get_connector_properties?

But I have to facepalm, because I'm not sure now that my request was such a good idea.

If we issue that warning here we'll be seeing this warning on ALL systems, even those that are not using NVMe-oF devices.

The warning on L64 does not have this issue, because at that point we know that the caller is actually using the nvmeof connector.
-1: Sorry, I'm against this, as I believe it makes the code harder to read. In my mind it's not **any** "executor" it's self.

I see now that my comment is not very clear.  What I mean to say is that it should not be a static method but a normal instance method.

def _is_native_multipath_supported(self):

-1: We cannot blindly use the class attribute here, because in general this method is called before instantiating this class, so on the first time this method is called it will return None as the value.

Once the connector is instantiated for the first time (for example to connect a volume) the value will be correct.

We can solve this by changing the "_is_native_multipath_supported" to something that checks the class attribute and only looks for it if it's not set.

eg:

  def __init__(...):
     self._set_native_multipath_supported()
     if self.use_multipath and not \
             NVMeOFConnector.native_multipath_supported:
         LOG.warning('native multipath is not enabled')


  def get_connector_properties(...):
         . . .
      ret['nvme_native_multipath'] = cls._set_native_multipath_supported()
         . . .

  @classmethod
  def _set_native_multipath_supported(cls):
      if cls.native_multipath_supported is None:
          cls.native_multipath_supported = cls._is_native_multipath_supported()
      return cls.native_multipath_supported


We can even include the _is_native_multipath_supported code in the set method.

nit: Address is readable by everyone on the system, so we don't need privileged access to read it and we can read it in Python instead of running a subcommand.

        no_multipath = (not executor.use_multipath

I think that such changes require release note
https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/contributor/releasenotes.html

It looks like _set_instance_obj_error_state is used on multiple occasions in nova/compute/manager.py. In some cases clean_task_state=False (default makes sense for me). Examples: [1], [2], [3] and [4].

For [4] we explicitly break behavior described in _error_out_instance_on_exception docstring. As a result, I think that a careful second look is needed here: maybe adding clean_task_state=True to some _set_instance_obj_error_state calls would make more sense.

Please let me know if I am missing something.

[1]
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/compute/manager.py#L1145

[2]
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/compute/manager.py#L1307

[3]
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/compute/manager.py#L3183

[4]
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/compute/manager.py#L10374

There is only one case that is to delete the instance and the task state cannot be None if the state is error. Because we want to delete the instance again when the compute is initialing[2].
But this case only occurs when the compute service becomes down unexpectly and the service is up again. In addtion, if the service is down immediately, the instance state won't be error.

And for other cases, it's no need to keep the task_state if the instance's state is error. Because we also want to rescure the instance if the instance becomes error because of our actions. And it will be more diffcult for us if the instance's task state is not none.

There is another qeustion, for the case that delete the instance failure, and the instance task state is not set to None. For this case, if we want to try delete the instance again, it will be reject to this action[2].

For these reasons, I think
reference:
[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/compute/api.py#L2660
[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/compute/manager.py#L1131

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Thank you very much. Great improvement!

The original intention of adding a separate Overrides option was to keep users to use the original SshOptions to "remove" any line in the default value. The behavior has been kept for several cycles so I was concerned about breaking any existing usage.

However seeing multiple cases where users face problems when they try to use this parameter expecting it would be merged, I feel like that removal would be quite rare compared to override. So I'm good with this change.
We indeed got customer cases caused by this confusion. Keeping only one option, and calling the "merge" thingy is far easier to maintain and understand. Thank you Rabi!

doc/source/shared/abbrevs.txt.message: This is not on our list of unbiased terms. Is there an alternative?

There has not been and update to the standard (IEEE 1588) to use neutral language, and while the linuxptp community has been updating their terms independently, they have not decided on a replacement term for GM and are still using Grand Master.

All that is to say that there is not a clear industry consensus on what to use here, so we are pretty much on our own.

I'm open to suggestions if another term is preferred. One that I have seen in the linuxptp community that has been tossed around is Primary Time Source (PTS).

These are the BIOS and UEFI grub files used to pxeboot controller-0 from an external boot server. They are template files that PV tailors for each system using sed on the xxYYYYxxx variable replacements.

These files are presently not packaged in the load and never have been, even in CentOS.

I feel they should be put under version control and have posted them here to get feedback on their content for Debian.

These menus will be used in the installer customer documentation.

I think this needs some more work.  Here's what I'm worried about.

This change is involved in 3 workflows:

1. Upload volume to image - POST /v3/{project_id}/volumes/{volume_id}/action with the 'os-volume_upload_image' action
- this has complete test coverage, so I'm not worried about it

2. Create a volume - POST /v3/{project_id}/volumes with an 'imageRef' attribute in the request body
- the code that raises ImageUnacceptable isn't called until taskflow is running, so what will happen (I think) is that the user gets a 202, but the volume ultimately goes to 'error' status
- I don't think the user gets any feedback about what went wrong?
- there are some user messages created in cinder/volume/flows/api/create_volume.py, but not one that would handle ImageUnacceptable

3. Reimage a volume - POST /v3/{project_id}/volumes/{volume_id}/action with the 'os-reimage' action
- the check doesn't happen until *after* the rpcapi call is made; user gets a 202 but volume goes to 'error' status
- I think you should add a user message for this case (code is in cinder/volume/manager.py, which creates user messages for other situations)
It appears that my concerns have been addressed.

1. First of all, this is a tuneable knob, if you don't WANT to enable it, you don't have to.
2. Glance does handle this just fine.  However, it is possible to have a environment where Nova creates VMs on local disks on hypervisors (QCOW2 is great for this), but Cinder volumes being created from QCOW2 images will absolutely *destroy* your control plane.  In this case, I would like to allow both QCOW2 and RAW, but I don't want QCOW2 being converted to RAW in my control plane if someone wants to boot from volume.
3. Interoperable image import is a new feature.  It also relies on converting on the control plane, that is *not* functional at large scale unpredictable public clouds.

If you have a user that uploads a 200MB QCOW2 image that is 2TB in virtual size, then immediately start to spin up 100 VMs using it, good luck with this.  Cinder will download 200MB x 100 times, then convert 200MB x 100, and being 2TB in virtual size, it WILL write ~200TB to disk, and then upload 200T to Ceph.  It just doesn't scale.

Once again, it's a tuneable, if someone feels like don't want to change the behaviour, they don't have to.
```

It's indeed current Glance options doesn't seems able to fix the issue without coding in cinder. IMO, as Mohammed mentioned, even you set glance image conversion plugin config [1] and disk_formats config [2] all right, What will happen is you gonna generate new image through qemu-img in cinder ([3]) anyway before upload it to glance. So Glance will always get the `right` format of file in this case. But under certain scale of request, your services will probably directly went down.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/glance/latest/admin/interoperable-image-import.html#the-image-conversion
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/glance/src/branch/master/glance/common/config.py#L95-L101
[3] https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/src/branch/master/cinder/image/image_utils.py#L381

I've put in a lot of effort reviewing this patch, and if you trace back through its history you'll see that it has had to evolve to correctly address the 3 workflows that will be impacted by this change.  So I'm not unsympathetic to the proposal.  I asked some other cores to look at it to make sure that there aren't any other workflows I missed, and the feedback I got was that we need to have some discussion about whether this configuration option is necessary.  So I asked Rajat to put a hold on the patch until the cinder team has had time to discuss it at our weekly meeting.

I thought the first paragraph of Rajat's comment with the -2 was pretty clear about why it was assigned.  Maybe a -W is more appropriate, but I personally don't know if those are "sticky" like a -2 is, and we've traditionally used -2s for this purpose in Cinder, particularly if there's already been a +2 on a patch on some point.

So, I'm renewing the -2 on this patch to put a hold on it until after we've had time to discuss it.
Lifting my -2, as we've discussed the patch at today's cinder meeting.

There are certain reasons why this doesn't seem like a valid approach (at least to me) so I would request the authors to join the cinder meeting[1] to discuss this in detail. I will lift my -2 when we reach a positive consensus regarding this approach.

We already have options in glance that could perform the functionality and since we are dealing with "images", this should better be handled at the glance side (with the existing mechanism).

We have a config option disk_formats[2] which allows us to choose which image format we want to allow or not.

We also have the image conversion plugin[3] that should handle most of the cases if we want to allow operations with minimal conversions:
1) create volume from image: set the output format of image same as the volume format to avoid conversion with every new volume create request
2) reimage volume: same as 1 for new image
3) upload volume to image: provide image disk format same as the volume format

[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/CinderMeetings#Weekly_Cinder_team_meeting
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/glance/src/branch/master/glance/common/config.py#L95-L101
[3] https://docs.openstack.org/glance/latest/admin/interoperable-image-import.html#the-image-conversion

I'm not sure how a -1 helps in this case when it gets removed with a patch update. My initial intentions of the -2 was just to hold further discussions for this (which I've quite clearly mentioned in my comment) but looks like it has been taken into a different context and for the same reason I will lift it to clear things up.

I fully disagree with this, and I fully disagree that this is a -2 worthy comment after 17 days of going back and forth on this patch.

1. First of all, this is a tuneable knob, if you don't WANT to enable it, you don't have to.
2. Glance does handle this just fine.  However, it is possible to have a environment where Nova creates VMs on local disks on hypervisors (QCOW2 is great for this), but Cinder volumes being created from QCOW2 images will absolutely *destroy* your control plane.  In this case, I would like to allow both QCOW2 and RAW, but I don't want QCOW2 being converted to RAW in my control plane if someone wants to boot from volume.
3. Interoperable image import is a new feature.  It also relies on converting on the control plane, that is *not* functional at large scale unpredictable public clouds.

If you have a user that uploads a 200MB QCOW2 image that is 2TB in virtual size, then immediately start to spin up 100 VMs using it, good luck with this.  Cinder will download 200MB x 100 times, then convert 200MB x 100, and being 2TB in virtual size, it WILL write ~200TB to disk, and then upload 200T to Ceph.  It just doesn't scale.

Once again, it's a tuneable, if someone feels like don't want to change the behaviour, they don't have to.

This is not correct. An ImageUnacceptable exception could occur because of many reasons as follows:

1) When CONF.allow_compression_on_image_upload is False but container_format provided is 'compressed'
2) qemu-img command failed
3) Wrong compression format provided etc

We should not misguide the user into thinking it's because of the format of image and volume. Also we should not assume that the config option is always set to True, we should add a check for that as well before creating specific messages like this.

How about we use error messages to check if it is the ImageUnacceptable error we're looking for. Because we might also face that other ImageUnacceptable jump out first before image_conversion_disable check. Make sure we don't rise here if it's other errors happen but also satisfy both  `CONF.image_conversion_disable` and `disk_format!=volume_type`.

A few thoughts here:

- the important thing is to get useful info out to the user, so if the only way to do that is to parse the message in the exception, that's OK with me.  If we have a unit test that looks for the message, then if the message is changed, the test should break, and we should be able to detect that before a regression happens.  It's kind a stupid unit test, but 

- we could fix this (though I haven't thought it through) by refactoring the ImageUnacceptable exception and giving it a detail member that could take a value of type cinder.message.message_field.Detail, and then that field could be loaded at the point of the error, when you know exactly what caused it

- or we could simply refactor the error messages for each of the ImageUnacceptable messages to include a specific string that the code could look for to decide what Detail to use.  Problem here is that we'd need to keep a list of the specific strings somewhere, which would be dumb since we have the Detail fields defined already.

- looking at the Exception message raised here is making me reconsider the design of our user messages ... it contains explicit detail about what happened without revealing any deployment details

Most of this is beyond the scope of this change, though.

I'm not really a fan of using specific message to be used to raise an exception or in general for any conditional as we can change a log or error message any time causing the regression. I don't even prefer it in test cases but guess we don't have a choice there.
Having said that I will let other cores take a look and see what they think about it.
Since you know what detail message you want to use, don't pass the exception.  (If you really want to know why not, the user messages contributor docs explain it.)

The setting.cfg is not directly passed to setuptools but it is first parsed by pbr, which uses [metadata] parameters and generates options for setuptools.

The following line describes the mapping between [metadata] python_requires and [option] python_requires.
 https://github.com/openstack/pbr/blob/5ded0ee1ff7236aa6bdc94cf5f4426b3816c98ef/pbr/util.py#L117

My understanding is that you can use the native interface of setuptools while pbr provides more sophisticated structure. Using [options] would work but I'll keep usage of [metadata] since that is globally used in the other OpenStack projects.

glean/cmd.py.message:
The three _write_rh_* calls above all modify a new dict instead of updating the passed dict like _write_rh_v6_interface does. The old code used dict.update() to add in the configs. The new code uses assignment which will override the data instead.

I'm concerned that we are changing behavior but this may be correct because we are trying to treat ipv4, ipv4_dhcp, and manual as exclusive situations? At the very least maybe we need to log that situation?

Thanks, good catch.

I *think* this is safe, because the only combo it makes sense to have both of is ipv4+ipv6 (i.e. doesn't make sense to have ipv4 and ipv4_dhcp).  So these other ones won't overwrite each other.

However, moving this back to directly update the files_to_write dict should make this clearer.  I've done that in the new revision, and also added an else clause to log if we're falling out of this and not handling something we don't know about.

This appears to work in local repl testing but calling out that this is roughly equivalent to:

  d = { 'foo': 'bar'}
  d.update(d)

You can probably drop the d.update() call on this case or keep it for consistency since repl testing shows it is probably fine.

The core problem is that Octavia registers some parameters to health_manager section but these parameters are actually used not only by health manager but also by worker. This is quite confusing and we'd need to consider a different section if the parameters are needed by two services, IMO.

I tend to keep the current structure which registers the health_manager options to the health_manager class which helps us to look up the parameters earsily.
This would not be the problem if a deployment have two services collocated. If not, then users can include octavia::health_manager with service/package management disabled.

I'm trying to avoid having to do this as it is prone to human error and makes it more complicated. We got caught out with this in production. Ideally if you include the octavia::worker class it should configure everything it needs.

I can't figure out a better way than to specify this option in a class that will be used by both worker and health_manager

glean/cmd.py.message: Should we also skip route setting if relying on slaac? RAs can set multiple routes iirc.

Yes, routers can announce routes to all the networks they're connected to, the default route is merely a special case. Also you can receive route announcements from multiple routers connected to different networks, and even end up with multiple routes to the same destination (including default routes), in which case the stack makes decisions on which gateway wins for a given destination based on a variety of heuristics.

kernel-modules/qat17/debian/deb_folder/r.message:
Hi Li,

While your solution will work, I wonder if the correct approach is to align the library installation directory to Debian. /usr/lib64 sounds more like Red Hat/Fedora-oriented.

If I recall correctly, Debian uses /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/ as the library installation directory. The x86_64-... directory name could perhaps be acquired with something like the following:

```
dpkg-architecture --query DEB_HOST_GNU_TYPE
```

Reference regarding build/host/target: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/5139403/whats-the-difference-of-configure-option-build-host-and-target
I agree with Vefa, instead of adding another directory to look in during load, investigate if the files were put in the right directory in the first place.

We could most likely get away with just '_libdir=/usr/lib', but if we are going to package this as a multilib we should follow the Debian guidance from

https://www.debian.org/doc/manuals/maint-guide/advanced.en.html#multiarch

and instead of what you have use

_libdir=/usr/lib/$(shell dpkg-architecture -qDEB_HOST_MULTIARCH)
I see you made the change to use /usr/lib, I assume the testing passed still. And if so please mark this comment as resolved and I can pass the review.

Done.

This feature isn't used by now, but in CentOS's version of linuxptp it creates a default entry (with generic/wrong service name) if not explicitly defined like in the code. On the other hand, that feature isn't available yet in the latest linuxptp version available for Debian.
Thus, for CentOS we just create the proper entry in the .conf file of PTP to avoid setting a wrong value there, but don't use it. In Debian, we dismiss the entry at all.
